content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: J'ai mis plus de temps que prévu pour valider tous les tests mais je pense que ça peut être intéressant de voir combien de cas différents on peut valider en 15 minutes

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It looks quite simple for a clash of code comp and i think it can be finished fast enough

I agree that it's a bit complex for a clash. Have you considered having a dynamical number of children with varying names and making it a puzzle ? With "I did not see who stole it" as an option for their second statement.

- Someone confesses : they stole it.
- More than one kid confesses : the culprit is the one who's been seen by the most other kids
- No one confesses but no one saw it : None of them did.
- No one confesses but several kids claim to have seen something : the kid with the most accusers is the most likely culprit
- No one confesses but several kids have the same number of accusers : Either So or So stole it.
- No one confesses but all the others say they have seen the same kid : That kid stole it (not just "likely culprit")

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: All good. Checked the test logic, makes sense.
Its fun but takes quite some time for a clash

Cases
* Validator 1: Please change Bob's second statement to its negation so that the scenario becomes a simple reflection of Test 1.

* Please create a new pair of cases using the original Validator 1 and its reflected version.

* There are theoretically 16 statement combinations. Currently, Test 2 and Validator 2 are the same, and so are Test 4 and Validator 4. Can some of the remaining combinations be added as additional pairs of cases?

Thanks.

Let "A" denote a "_ stole the gift" statement from Alice, and "a" denote a "_ did not steal the gift" statement. Similar for Bob, let "B" and "b" denote the two statements.

Then, the theoretical 16 possibilities are:
(1) AABB: not valid, Alice and Bob cannot both steal the gift
(2) AABb: not valid, same as (1)
(3) AAbB: valid
(4) AAbb: not valid, Bob must be truthful (bB only)
(5) AaBB: not valid, same as (1)
(6) AaBb: not valid, same as (1)
(7) AabB: valid, test 1
(8) Aabb: not valid, same as (4)
(9) aABB: valid, validator 1
(10) aABb: valid
(11) aAbB: valid, test/validator 4
(12) aAbb: valid, test 3
(13) aaBB: not valid, Alice must be truthful (aA only)
(14) aaBb: not valid, same as (13)
(15) aabB: valid, validator 3
(16) aabb: valid, test/validator 2

I can add one more test case for combinations (3) and (10), but that's about it unfortunately.

Edit: Combinations (7) and (10) now make up test/validator 1, while combinations (9) and (3) make up test/validator 5.

Thanks for the feedback @Hall_Alexandra! Indeed, I have thought about making this a puzzle, but that would make this problem exponentially harder. It would require a clear definition of statement types and culprit behaviour, and would most likely require (at least) one culprit for statements to be logically deducible. I'm not sure I entirely agree with the culprit being labelled based on the one claimed to have been seen the most, as you suggest.

What are your thoughts on the current clash? Based on your suggestion, I assume that you did manage to deduce the logic, perhaps after some time of thinking. Do you think this clash is doable within 5 minutes, or maybe 10 minutes?
Thanks for the approval @ZenGuy. Do try coding out a solution and let me know if it was simple enough to implement! :)
yep it was pretty simple to implement too
I did eventually work it out, but I took more than 15 minutes. That might say more about my skills than about the clash, though ^^
Might be fun to see how many test cases one can get right in a 15-minute window, though
I agree with your analysis; it boils down to the first two points of my first comment.
